Aspartic acid
Aspartic acid
Aspartic acid is a nonessential
amino acid
. Amino acids are building blocks of proteins.
"Nonessential" means that our bodies produce it, even if we do not get this amino acid from the food we eat.
Information
Aspartic acid helps every cell in the body work. It plays a role in:
Hormone production and release
Normal
nervous system
function
Plant sources of aspartic acid include:
Avocado
Asparagus
Molasses
Animal sources of aspartic acid include:
Wild game
Oysters
Meat and poultry
Alternative Names
Asparaginic acid
References
Dietzen DJ, Willrich MAV. Amino acids, peptides, and proteins. In: Rifai N, Chiu RWK, Young I, Burnham Carey-Ann D, Wittwer CT, eds.
Tietz Textbook of Laboratory Medicine
. 7th ed. St Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2023:chap 31.

Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology
. 14th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2021:chap 70.
Mason JB. Nutritional principles and assessment of the gastroenterology patient.
